_exec_summary.SummaryText:
single vessel evaluated. Using the EPA OCA Guidance, the entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite. This results in a vapor cloud explosion impacting an area with a 0.4 mile radius before a level of 1 psi overpressure is reached. RMP COMP Version 1.07 was used for this analysis. 

The facility is not located in a populated area; therefore, the WCS would not affect a public receptor and is considered a Program 1 process.  All other release scenarios fall within the area of the WCS as well.  A consideration of the 0.4 mile radius has been incorporated into our notification and emergency response planning.

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Chester Gas Plant is covered by the OSHA PSM Program to aid in accident release prevention. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Chester Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention.  There have been only two minor accidental releases in the past five years from the covered process.  The first accident involved a release of methane gas for five minutes.  The accident injured three onsite personnel and resulted in onsite and offsite property damage.  Offsite responders were notified and responded.  Many changes were introduced at the plant as a result of the accident; including improved/upgraded equipment and revised maintenance, training, and operation procedures.  In addition, a revised emergency response plan was also introduced.     

The second accident involved a 3-5 second release of y-grade condensate. This accident injured one onsite contractor and resulted in minor onsite property damage.  Offsite responders were not notified.  However, several changes were introduced as a result of the accident; including revised maintenance, training, and operating procedures.  

Neither accident resulted in an onsite death or an offsite death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, or environmental damage.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

Targa's Chester Gas Plant is a Non-Res

ponding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of Targa staff, local emergency response agencies, and the public if a release occurs. However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the facility would rely on the local fire department to respond.  

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.  The Chester Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  

ORGANIZATIONAL CHART
The following provides a facility organizational chart with respect to RMP responsibilities.

NAME: Clint Duty
TITLE: Vice President, EH&S
REPORTS TO: Pat McDonie, President
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Oversight of corporate RMP implementation, environmental compliance, and regulatory compliance.

NAME: Ernie Hiland
TITLE: Supervisor, Plants
REPORTS TO: Arnie Krush, Area Manager
RESPONSIBILITIES:  Oversight of plant level RMP implementation, spill prevention, response record-keeping, training, and inspections. Primary response coordinator.

NAME/TITLE: Area Supervisors
REPORTS TO: Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Assist Coordinators with RMP implementation & report incidents

NAME/TITLE: Onsite Personnel
REPORTS TO: Area Supervisors & Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents

NAM

E/TITLE: Onsite Contractors
REPORTS TO: Response Coordinators
RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

There are currently no specific planned changes to improve safety. Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued improvement to the level of safety at the Chester Gas Plant. Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:

The OSHA Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

The OSHA PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continued improvements in our safety standards. 

The OSHA Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.

The Chester Gas Plant has annual training on the emergency response plan. This training has included the local emergency response groups including, local ambulance services and the local fire departments. These training sessions are audited by Targa Safety Personnel.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent WestOK, LLC 
Chester Gas Plant (Facility ID: 100000187102)

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
Targa Pipeline Mid-Continent WestOK, LLC (Targa) owns and operates a non-fractionating natural gas plant, the Chester Gas Plant, in Woodward County, Oklahoma.  The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid products from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means.  Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.
The Chester Gas Plant has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Chester Gas Plant is located near Chester, Oklahoma in Woodward County. Targa treats the entire gas plant as one process with 392,655 lbs of flammable substances. The facility operates the process to produce the following petroleum products:

1. Y grade mixture from natural gas
2. Condensate
3. Residue Gas

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS (OCA) RESULTS

Several vessels at the gas plant were evaluated for the offsite consequence analysis.  There is one worst-case scenario (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at the Chester Gas Plant.  A vapor could explosion involving 120,450 pounds (30,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in an intermediate pressure flash tank (V-110).  This is the largest
